Award.AwardTitle: Summer School on Surgery and the Classification of Manifolds
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial support towards the travel of US-based early-career mathematicians to the "Summer School on Surgery and the Classification of Manifolds" held at the University of Calgary, Alberta, Canada, on July 18-22, 2016. This international event is sponsored by the Pacific Institute of Mathematical Sciences (PIMS) Collaborative Research Group (CRG) in Applied, Algebraic, and Geometric Topology. Manifolds are geometric objects that locally resemble flat space. For example, the surface of a doughnut is a two-dimensional manifold called a torus. The technique of surgery, which involves cutting and pasting pieces of manifolds, allows a transition from questions in geometry to quantifiable and easier questions in algebra. The technique of surgery is a central area of mathematics, but it is quite difficult to learn because it draws on many other areas. This summer school is an educational outreach program designed to make the techniques of surgery and manifold topology accessible to a wide range of graduate students and junior mathematicians. The program includes lectures by experts, mini-lectures by participants on background topics, and exercise sessions mentored by experts. Graduate students, junior faculty, women, minorities, and persons with disabilities are especially encouraged to participate and to apply for support.

Classification of manifolds is a central area of geometric topology and intersects with many other fields, including analysis, geometry, algebra, and group theory. This summer school aims to stimulate education and research in classification of manifolds and related areas of mathematics. Participants will have diverse mathematical backgrounds, with knowledge in geometric topology, algebraic topology, geometric group theory, differential geometry, and geometric functional analysis. Depending on interest, participants will have different take-aways from the summer school. A geometric topologist may learn about handle analysis and the specifics of the topology of manifolds. An algebraic topologist might learn about how classifying spaces, generalized (co)homology theories, and algebraic K-theory are used in practice. A geometer might learn about metrics of positive scalar curvature and tools for the topological classification of manifolds with geometric structure. A geometric group theorist might learn about applications of (co)homology of groups and large scale geometry. A geometric functional analyst would learn about a world parallel to that of C*-algebras and noncommutative geometry. The website of the summer school is http://www.pims.math.ca/scientific-event/160718-ssscm

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Summer School on Surgery and Classification of Manifolds took place July 18-22, 2016 at the University of Calgary, in Calgary, Alberta, Canada. Manifolds, geometric objects which resemble Euclidean space, arise throughout theoretical and applied mathematics.    Manifolds are the key object of study in geometric topology.  Surgery (a cutting and pasting technique) is the key tool in classification of high-dimensional manifolds and is useful for low-dimensional topology as well.

The main objective of the summer school was to provide an introduction to surgery theory for young mathematicians who needed expertise in this useful and many-faceted subject, and to stimulate and encourage research in this area.   The organizers felt that it was important to have such an event in North America, since there has been several summer schools in Europe and one in Asia. There was a satellite event Surgery and Geometry at Banff, which was a research conference designed in conjunction with the Summer School.  This research conference allowed advanced participants to lecture on their own research and be exposed to the state of the art in Classification of Manifolds.  

The scientific organizers were Diarmuid Crowley and James Davis, and the local organizer was Kristine Bauer.   The main lecturers were Diarmuid Crowley, James Davis, and Qayum Khan.   Scientific lectures were given by experts Don Stanley and Ian Hambleton, and the capstone lectures (on Friday) were given by Guoliang Yu, who described deep connections between surgery and analysis.   There were 40 participants; they were an international group of talented Ph.D. students and postdocs.   27 of the participants were from institutions in the United States, and their participation was made possible by the NSF grant.   

The event took a great deal of preparation, for example we arranged sponsorship from the Pacific Institute of Mathematical Sciences and the University of Calgary, as well as the National Science Foundation.   We advertised the summer school widely, and had about 80 applicants for our 40 positions.   This meant that the organizers had difficult choices to make, but the selection guaranteed that the participants were a talented and diverse group.   

The event itself was wonderful.  Every day, there were 4 one-hour lectures by the experts, two one-half hour minilectures by the participants, and open-ended exercise sessions, mentored by experts in the subject.   The format was somewhat different on Friday due to Yu's capstone lectures and travel concerns.   

The 10 minilectures were high points for the 20 participants involved.   We prepared brief outlines for each of the minilectures, several months before the event and distributed them to the 40 participants, asked for 20 volunteers.   We choose the 20, and assigned two participants to each minilectures - one being the scribe and one being the lecturer.   The scribe prepared detailed notes and distributed them to the participants.  

The exercise sessions provided further opportunities for participation.   They were challenging (perhaps too challenging), and their successful solution - often a group effort - provided a real understanding of the subject of surgery.  

The website listed above is a permanent resource contains the exercises, the description of the lectures and minilectures as well as notes on surgery theory.  The one regret of the organizers is that we did not have the resources to film the lectures and minilectures.   

The Summer School had both intellectual merit in advancing knowledge in manifold theory and providing resources to participants for future advancement, and well as broader impacts, being essentially an educational outreach activity.
